children.text: Okay, I need to translate this Java code into Fortran.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Let me start by understanding what the Java code does. So the program reads an integer n from input, then reads n integers into a list.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The main logic is determining the earliest time when there's a gap of more than 15 minutes between consecutive elements.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The result is the first position where this gap occurs plus 15, or the last element plus 15, but not exceeding 90.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Also, if the first element is over 15, the result is 15.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: First, I'll need to handle input in Fortran.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Java uses a Scanner, but Fortran reads from standard input using READ statements.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: So, I'll start by reading n, then reading an array of n integers.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The first check is if the first element is greater than 15. If so, result is 15.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Otherwise, loop through the array from the second element to see if the difference between current and previous is >15. If found, set flag and break.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Then, depending on flag, set result to a[pos]+15 or the last element +15. Also, cap the result at 90.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Let me structure this step by step. First, read n. Then allocate a with size n. Then read the elements.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Now, handling the initial condition: if a(1) >15 (Fortran is 1-based), then result is 15. Else, loop from i=2 to n, check a(i) -a(i-1) >15. If yes, set pos to i-1, flag=1, break.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Wait, in Java, the list is 0-based. So in Fortran, the indices start at 1. So when Java checks a.get(i) - a.get(i-1), for i starting at 1, that's equivalent to Fortran's i starting at 2. So in the loop, i would be from 2 to n.

If such a gap is found, then pos is i-1 (Java's index) which in Fortran would be (i-1) as well, but since i in Fortran starts at 2, i-1 is 1-based here. Wait, maybe not. Let's think:
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: In Java, for i from 1 to n-1 (since the loop runs i from 1 to i <n), checking a[i] and a[i-1]. So for the array [a0, a1, a2, ... a(n-1)], i runs from 1 to n-1. So in Fortran, the array is a(1) to a(n), and i runs from 2 to n. Because a(i) - a(i-1) would compare each consecutive pair. So the loop in Fortran should be from i=2 to n. Wait, the original Java loop is for (int i = 1; i < n; i++). So for i in 1 to n-1 (since Java's for loop is until i <n). Then comparing a.get(i) and a.get(i-1). So in Fortran, the indices are 1-based, so the same comparison would be between a(i) and a(i-1) for i from 2 to n. So the loop in Fortran is from i=2 to n.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: So, in the Fortran code, after reading the array, check if a(1) >15. If so, set result=15. Else, loop from i=2 to n, check if a(i)-a(i-1) >15. If any such occurrence, set pos = i-1 (Fortran's index here is i-1, which would be the previous element's position). Then set flag=1 and exit loop.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Wait, in Java, pos is set to i-1 (the index of the previous element).
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: In Fortran terms, when i is the current loop index (starting at 2), a(i) is the current element, a(i-1) is the previous. So the gap is between a(i) and a(i-1).
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: If the gap is >15, then the pos is i-1 (the index of the previous element in Fortran's 1-based array).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Then, the result is a(pos) +15.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: If no gaps are found, then the result is a(n) +15.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Then, check if result exceeds 90. If so, cap at 90. So putting it all together:

Read n.

Allocate a(n). Read a.

If a(1) >15, result=15. Else: Initialize flag=0, pos=0. Loop i from 2 to n:

      if (a(i) - a(i-1) >15) then

          pos = i-1

          flag =1

          exit loop

      end if

   end loop

   if (flag==1) then

      result = a(pos) +15

   else

      result = a(n) +15

   endif
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Then, if result>90, set to 90. Print result. Now, handling edge cases. For example, if n is zero? But according to the problem, n is given as input.
children.label: test_generation

children.text: Wait, the Java code reads n and then reads exactly n elements. So in Fortran, assuming n is at least 1?
children.label: test_generation

children.text: Well, the code as written in Java starts with n, and then reads n elements. So in Fortran, the same. Another edge case: if all elements are <=90 and the sum is beyond 90.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: For example, if the last element is 85, then +15 is 100, which is capped to 90.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text:
Now, translating to Fortran:

Variables needed: n, a as integer array, result, pos, flag.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
Declarations:

integer :: n, i, value, result, pos, flag

integer, allocatable :: a(:)

Read n from input. Then allocate a(n). Read a from input.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Wait, in Fortran, can read all elements at once. So read(*,*) a(:) Then process. So code steps:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, i, pos, flag, result
    integer, allocatable :: a(:)
    
    read(*,*) n
    allocate(a(n))
    read(*,*) a
    
    if (a(1) > 15) then
        result = 15
    else
        flag = 0
        pos = 0 do i = 2, n
            if (a(i) - a(i-1) > 15) then
                pos = i-1
                flag = 1
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (flag == 1) then
            result = a(pos) + 15
        else
            result = a(n) + 15
        end if
    end if
    
    if (result > 90) then
        result = 90
    end if
    
    print *, result
    
end program

Wait, but in the Java code, after checking the first element, the else part includes the loop. But in Fortran, the code structure is similar. But need to make sure that when n is 1.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: For example, if n is 1, then the loop from 2 to n won't run. So, if n=1, then the code checks a(1) >15. If yes, result 15. Else, enters else part.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The loop doesn't run, so flag remains 0. So result is a(1) +15. Then check if exceeds 90. That's correct. Testing some examples.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text:
Original Java code example:

Suppose input is 2 1 16. Then a is [1,16].
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The difference is 15, which is not >15. So result is 16+15=31, which is under 90.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Another example: input is 3 15 30 45. The differences are 15, 15. No gaps. So result is 45+15=60.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Another example: input is 5 10 25 40 55 70. The gaps are 15, 15, 15, 15. So result is 70+15=85.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: If the input is 1 10: result is 25.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: If input is 1 16: first element is 16>15, so result 15.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Another case where a gap exists: input 4 10 20 40 60.
children.label: test_generation

children.text: The difference between 20 and 40 is 20>15. So pos is 2 (the index of 20), result is 20+15=35. Then check if 35>90? No. So output 35.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: What if the result after adding 15 is 100? Then it's capped to 90.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Now, in Fortran, the code should handle these cases. Potential issues:
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: In Fortran, when reading the array, if the input is given as a single line, the read(*,*) a will read all elements. But if the input is given with elements on separate lines, it should still work. But the Java code uses nextInt() which reads tokens, so same as Fortran's list-directed read.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Another thing: in Fortran, if the array is read with read(*,*) a, then each element is read from input. So the code should handle that. Testing the code with n=0? But in Java, the code reads n, then creates an array list. If n=0, the loop runs 0 times. But in Fortran, allocating a(0) is allowed?
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Probably not, but the problem probably assumes n is a positive integer as per the code's logic. The original code's input would have n as a positive integer, but in practice, need to handle n=0.
children.label: test_generation

children.text: However, in the Java code, if n is zero, the code would throw an error when checking a.get(0). So perhaps the problem assumes n is at least 1. So the Fortran code as written would work under the same assumptions.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Therefore, the translated code should work as intended.
children.label: empty

children.text: In Java, they use an ArrayList.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: In Fortran, I can use an allocatable array. So declare the array with INTEGER, ALLOCATABLE :: a(:), then allocate it once n is read. Next, the logic.
children.label: high_level_plan

tree.original_reasoning:
Okay, I need to translate this Java code into Fortran. Let me start by understanding what the Java code does. 

So the program reads an integer n from input, then reads n integers into a list. The main logic is determining the earliest time when there's a gap of more than 15 minutes between consecutive elements. The result is the first position where this gap occurs plus 15, or the last element plus 15, but not exceeding 90. Also, if the first element is over 15, the result is 15.

First, I'll need to handle input in Fortran. Java uses a Scanner, but Fortran reads from standard input using READ statements. So, I'll start by reading n, then reading an array of n integers.

In Java, they use an ArrayList. In Fortran, I can use an allocatable array. So declare the array with INTEGER, ALLOCATABLE :: a(:), then allocate it once n is read.

Next, the logic. The first check is if the first element is greater than 15. If so, result is 15. Otherwise, loop through the array from the second element to see if the difference between current and previous is >15. If found, set flag and break. Then, depending on flag, set result to a[pos]+15 or the last element +15. Also, cap the result at 90.

Let me structure this step by step.

First, read n. Then allocate a with size n. Then read the elements.

Now, handling the initial condition: if a(1) >15 (Fortran is 1-based), then result is 15. Else, loop from i=2 to n, check a(i) -a(i-1) >15. If yes, set pos to i-1, flag=1, break.

Wait, in Java, the list is 0-based. So in Fortran, the indices start at 1. So when Java checks a.get(i) - a.get(i-1), for i starting at 1, that's equivalent to Fortran's i starting at 2. So in the loop, i would be from 2 to n.

If such a gap is found, then pos is i-1 (Java's index) which in Fortran would be (i-1) as well, but since i in Fortran starts at 2, i-1 is 1-based here. Wait, maybe not. Let's think:

In Java, for i from 1 to n-1 (since the loop runs i from 1 to i <n), checking a[i] and a[i-1]. So for the array [a0, a1, a2, ... a(n-1)], i runs from 1 to n-1. So in Fortran, the array is a(1) to a(n), and i runs from 2 to n. Because a(i) - a(i-1) would compare each consecutive pair.

So the loop in Fortran should be from i=2 to n. Wait, the original Java loop is for (int i = 1; i < n; i++). So for i in 1 to n-1 (since Java's for loop is until i <n). Then comparing a.get(i) and a.get(i-1). So in Fortran, the indices are 1-based, so the same comparison would be between a(i) and a(i-1) for i from 2 to n. So the loop in Fortran is from i=2 to n.

So, in the Fortran code, after reading the array, check if a(1) >15. If so, set result=15. Else, loop from i=2 to n, check if a(i)-a(i-1) >15. If any such occurrence, set pos = i-1 (Fortran's index here is i-1, which would be the previous element's position). Then set flag=1 and exit loop.

Wait, in Java, pos is set to i-1 (the index of the previous element). In Fortran terms, when i is the current loop index (starting at 2), a(i) is the current element, a(i-1) is the previous. So the gap is between a(i) and a(i-1). If the gap is >15, then the pos is i-1 (the index of the previous element in Fortran's 1-based array). Then, the result is a(pos) +15.

If no gaps are found, then the result is a(n) +15. Then, check if result exceeds 90. If so, cap at 90.

So putting it all together:

Read n.

Allocate a(n).

Read a.

If a(1) >15, result=15.

Else:

   Initialize flag=0, pos=0.

   Loop i from 2 to n:

      if (a(i) - a(i-1) >15) then

          pos = i-1

          flag =1

          exit loop

      end if

   end loop

   if (flag==1) then

      result = a(pos) +15

   else

      result = a(n) +15

   endif

Then, if result>90, set to 90.

Print result.

Now, handling edge cases. For example, if n is zero? But according to the problem, n is given as input. Wait, the Java code reads n and then reads exactly n elements. So in Fortran, assuming n is at least 1? Well, the code as written in Java starts with n, and then reads n elements. So in Fortran, the same.

Another edge case: if all elements are <=90 and the sum is beyond 90. For example, if the last element is 85, then +15 is 100, which is capped to 90.

Now, translating to Fortran:

Variables needed: n, a as integer array, result, pos, flag.

Declarations:

integer :: n, i, value, result, pos, flag

integer, allocatable :: a(:)

Read n from input.

Then allocate a(n).

Read a from input. Wait, in Fortran, can read all elements at once. So read(*,*) a(:)

Then process.

So code steps:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, i, pos, flag, result
    integer, allocatable :: a(:)
    
    read(*,*) n
    allocate(a(n))
    read(*,*) a
    
    if (a(1) > 15) then
        result = 15
    else
        flag = 0
        pos = 0
        do i = 2, n
            if (a(i) - a(i-1) > 15) then
                pos = i-1
                flag = 1
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (flag == 1) then
            result = a(pos) + 15
        else
            result = a(n) + 15
        end if
    end if
    
    if (result > 90) then
        result = 90
    end if
    
    print *, result
    
end program

Wait, but in the Java code, after checking the first element, the else part includes the loop. But in Fortran, the code structure is similar.

But need to make sure that when n is 1. For example, if n is 1, then the loop from 2 to n won't run. So, if n=1, then the code checks a(1) >15. If yes, result 15. Else, enters else part. The loop doesn't run, so flag remains 0. So result is a(1) +15. Then check if exceeds 90.

That's correct.

Testing some examples.

Original Java code example:

Suppose input is 2 1 16. Then a is [1,16]. The difference is 15, which is not >15. So result is 16+15=31, which is under 90.

Another example: input is 3 15 30 45. The differences are 15, 15. No gaps. So result is 45+15=60.

Another example: input is 5 10 25 40 55 70. The gaps are 15, 15, 15, 15. So result is 70+15=85.

If the input is 1 10: result is 25. If input is 1 16: first element is 16>15, so result 15.

Another case where a gap exists: input 4 10 20 40 60. The difference between 20 and 40 is 20>15. So pos is 2 (the index of 20), result is 20+15=35. Then check if 35>90? No. So output 35.

What if the result after adding 15 is 100? Then it's capped to 90.

Now, in Fortran, the code should handle these cases.

Potential issues:

In Fortran, when reading the array, if the input is given as a single line, the read(*,*) a will read all elements. But if the input is given with elements on separate lines, it should still work. But the Java code uses nextInt() which reads tokens, so same as Fortran's list-directed read.

Another thing: in Fortran, if the array is read with read(*,*) a, then each element is read from input. So the code should handle that.

Testing the code with n=0? But in Java, the code reads n, then creates an array list. If n=0, the loop runs 0 times. But in Fortran, allocating a(0) is allowed? Probably not, but the problem probably assumes n is a positive integer as per the code's logic. The original code's input would have n as a positive integer, but in practice, need to handle n=0. However, in the Java code, if n is zero, the code would throw an error when checking a.get(0). So perhaps the problem assumes n is at least 1.

So the Fortran code as written would work under the same assumptions.

Therefore, the translated code should work as intended.
